I believe that it's because students are not trained in using AI, thus the only way they know how to use AI is to receive answers from it. I wonder how we can help students understand AI as a tool? I completely agree—positioning AI as a tool rather than a crutch is essential, especially in K-12 settings where students are still developing foundational skills in critical thinking and digital literacy. The misuse or overreliance on AI often stems not from malintent, but from a lack of structured guidance on how to engage with AI thoughtfully and responsibly.To help students understand AI as a tool, I believe we need to embed AI literacy directly into the curriculum. This could include age-appropriate lessons on what AI is, how it works (in simplified terms), and what its limitations are. Practical activities that encourage students to interact with AI—such as prompting AI to brainstorm ideas, compare versions of text, or critique an AI-generated output—can help shift the mindset from passive consumption to active collaboration. ﻿@Ryoko Kitadai (she/her)﻿ said:I quite emphatically agree with the sentiment that "Learning is not only about absorbing information and education is not only about learning," involving also secondary layers that relate to different types of/multiple intelligences! It definitely does influence intrinsic motivation and one's ability to sustainably keep studying the material and construct a positive path forward!You're absolutely right that education goes far beyond simple information absorption. The point you raise about multiple intelligences and diverse learning styles is so important, especially in light of how often standardized approaches overlook these nuances. Your connection to intrinsic motivation is also key; when students feel seen and supported through varied modes of engagement, they’re far more likely to develop a sustained and meaningful relationship with the material. This part addresses a crucial but often underexplored dimension of AI integration in education: the socio-psychological barriers that hinder its effective use. It draws attention to the persistent challenge of student motivation, noting that only a small fraction—approximately 5%—engage with AI-enabled educational resources long enough to derive meaningful learning outcomes (Weatherholtz et al., 2022). This statistic underscores the need for designing AI tools that not only deliver content but also sustain learner engagement through personalized, interactive, and emotionally attuned experiences. It reimagines AI not as a tool of automation but as a cognitive partner that models complex learning phenomena to support the development and refinement of learners’ mental models. It encourages the design of low-automation, high-agency systems that foster metacognition and learner autonomy. This perspective invites rich pedagogical and ethical questions: How can AI be designed to prompt meaningful self-explanation and conceptual change? What kinds of data or language patterns best indicate a transformation in thinking? How can we ensure that such systems are accessible and culturally responsive, reflecting diverse ways of knowing rather than imposing narrow models of success? Finally, what role should teachers play in mediating student interactions with AI and interpreting computational representations of learning? I personally would like to agree with that sentence...and I was, actually, agreeing with it until recently. However, it seems that AI is becoming stronger and more powerful everyday, to the point where most of people are getting scared of being replaced by AI in their jobs. I don't want to sound pessimistic, and I really hope I am wrong on this one - but regarding the both fascinating and scary progress AI is making everyday in so many different fields, I now doubt that we can say that AI is still poor at many things. 2 years ago with the emergence of Midjourney or Stable Diffusion/ Dall-E, people where still clearly able to recognize and criticize an AI-generated picture. AI is now able to generate images, photographs, graphic design, illustration, poetry, essays, songs, etc as well as most artists. It is able to give you advice about law and legal procedure to the point to lawyers or legal advisers are feeling threatened. It is able to simulate a social interaction with a friend or a confident, reproduce human emotion or dialogue when you are in trouble, and simulate compassion and attention to the point where people are preferring virtual AI partners over real ones, or are using AI as a therapist. In the classroom, then, our task is not simply to ban or embrace AI wholesale, but to articulate clear pedagogical boundaries: we permit tools that scaffold students’ work (e.g. quick look‑ups or grammar checks) while requiring authentic engagement for tasks that assess critical thinking or original expression. By embedding AI literacy into our curriculum—teaching when and how to deploy these tools responsibly—we help students navigate that fine line between legitimate support and academic dishonesty, ensuring that productivity gains amplify rather than replace genuine learning. For education, this challenges the assumption that AI can serve as a substitute for deep learning or critical thinking ﻿@Macha Petre﻿  You raise an important and increasingly shared concern. As AI systems grow more sophisticated—capable of producing images, texts, and interactions that rival human outputs—it becomes harder to claim they are simply poor substitutes. However, while AI can now mimic the products of human labor with impressive accuracy, it still lacks the processes that give those products depth: intentionality, lived experience, ethical reasoning, and contextual understanding. Rather than dismissing AI’s progress, we might shift the conversation toward what uniquely human capacities we value and how education can cultivate them alongside, not in competition with, intelligent systems This passage importantly highlights that the success of AI in education is not just a technical issue, but a deeply human one. Motivation, trust, and sustained engagement are crucial for learners to benefit meaningfully from AI tools. The fact that only about 5% of students persist long enough to see real gains suggests a need to design AI tools that are not only intelligent but also emotionally and socially responsive. Without addressing these socio-psychological barriers, even the most advanced AI will fall short in real-world educational settings. "Stochastic parrot" really gets to the heart of how LLMs work and their limitations. They do not understand in the way that humans do but can imitate the ways that humans speak and given answers. The LLMs generate what is the most likely answer to the user's question given the data set available to the LLM.
